Description: Rim and body sherd (mended from three fragments) of Chian Wild Goat Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed black below; on top of rim, black line; exterior: at rim, dot and billet pattern between dilute lines; painted decoration consisting of sphinx (tip of wing, back, rump and tail remaining), to left; swastika, elaborate rosette and corner pendant roundel as filling ornament; at right, vertical dividing band consisting of broken maeander between parallel lines.
Curator's comments: The sherd joins British Museum 1924,1201.435 and 1924,1201.292. Lemos describes the sherd as belonging to the Group of Light-Walled Naukratis Animal Chalices. All sherds in this group are small and offer very little by way of information beyond the fact that they come from light-walled chalices. The decoration on sherds belonging to this group is also poorly or carelessly drawn (Lemos 1991, 981). However, the lack of decoration on the interior of the chalice, the metopal arrangement on the vase's exterior and the depiction of the sphinx and filling ornaments, which can find parallels with the sphinx and ornaments on the Aphrodite Bowl (British Museum 1888,0601.456), suggest that this chalice is of the Wild Goat Style.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. V, no. 24)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 93, p. 263, no. 547)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0168) (phase 2)
